'''Animal symbolicum''' ("symbol-making" or "symbolizing animal") is a [[List of alternative names for the human species|definition for humans]] proposed by the German [[neo-Kantian]] [[Ernst Cassirer]]. The tradition since [[Aristotle]] has defined a human being as ''animal rationale'' (a [[rational animal]]). However, Cassirer claimed that man's outstanding characteristic is not in his [[Metaphysics|metaphysical]] or physical nature, but rather in his work. [[Human]]ity cannot be known directly, but has to be known through the analysis of the symbolic universe that man has created historically. Thus man should be defined as ''animal symbolicum'' (a symbol-making or symbolizing animal). On this basis, Cassirer sought to understand [[human nature]] by exploring symbolic forms in all aspects of a human being's experience. His work is represented in his three-volume ''Philosophie der Symbolischen Formen'' (1923–9, translated as ''The Philosophy of Symbolic Forms'') and is summarized in his ''An Essay on Man''. [[W. J. T. Mitchell]] used this term in his essay on "representation" to say that
"man, for many philosophers both ancient and modern, is the "representational animal," ''homo symbolicum'' {{sic}}, the creature whose distinctive character is the creation and manipulation of signs - things that stand for or take the place of something else." McLaughlin, T. & Lentricchia, F. (1990). Critical Terms for [[Literary criticism|Literary Study]]. Chicago: [[University of Chicago|The University of Chicago]] press

{{Multiple issues| {{essay-like|date=June 2015}} {{globalize|date=May 2016}} }} [[File:Battle of Germany (1944) (Art.IWM ART LD 4526).jpg|thumb|''Battle of Germany'' by [[Paul Nash (artist)|Paul Nash]], 1944 ]] During World War II, the relations between art and war can be articulated around two main issues. First, art (and, more generally, culture) found itself at the centre of an ideological war. Second, during World War II, many artists found themselves in the most difficult conditions (in an occupied country, in [[Nazi concentration camp|internment camps]], in [[death camps]]) and their works are a testimony to a powerful "urge to create." Such creative impulse can be interpreted as the expression of self-preservation, a survival instinct in critical times.
==Historical context== [[File:Battle of Britain (Paul Nash).png|thumb|''Battle of Britain'' by [[Paul Nash (artist)|Paul Nash]], 1941]] War is a common theme in art and has inspired many great works. Throughout history, most representations of war depict military achievements and often show significant battle scenes. However, in the [[19th century]] a “turn” in the visual representation of war became noticeable. Artists started to show the disastrous aspects of war, instead of its glorified events and protagonists.<ref>Laurence Bertrand-Dorléac (ed.), ''Les désastres de la guerre, 1800-2014'', exh. cat., Lens, Musée du Louvre-Lens, Somogy, 2014 ; Laura Brandon, ''Art and War'', London: IB Tauris, 2007, p. 26-35</ref> Such a perspective is best exemplified by [[Francisco Goya]]’s series, [[The Disasters of War]] (1810-1820, first published in 1863), and [[Otto Dix]]’s portfolio, ''Der Krieg'' (published in 1924).
During [[World War II]], both traditions are present. For instance, [[Paul Nash (artist)|Paul Nash]]’s ''Battle of Britain'' ([[1941 in art|1941]]) represents a scene of aerial combat between British and [[Wehrmacht|German fighters]] over the [[English Channel]]. On the other hand, André Fougeron’s ''Street of Paris'' ([[1943 in art|1943]]) focuses on the impact of war and occupation on civilians.
==Art in Nazi Germany==
===Nazi art=== {{Main article|Art of the Third Reich}} {{See also|Paintings by Adolf Hitler}} [[File:The Worker and Kolkhoz Woman.jpg|thumb|''The Worker and Kolkhoz Woman'' by [[Vera Mukhina]], 1937]
In [[totalitarian]] regimes (especially in [[Hitler]]’s Germany), the control of art and other cultural expressions was an integral part of the establishment of power. It reflects totalitarianism’s aim to control every single aspect of society and the individuals’ lives. However, art and culture had a special importance because they have the power to influence people, and they embody the identity of a nation, a community, a group of people.]]
In [[Nazi Germany]], Hitler's cultural politic was twofold. The first step was a “[[cultural cleansing]]”. German culture and society were said to be in decline because forces of decadence had taken over and corrupted it (it is the idea of the “enemy within”).{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} The cultural cleansing was to be accompanied by a “rebirth” of German culture and society (Hitler had grand plans for several [[Führermuseum|museums]]), which involved an exaltation of the “true spirit” of the German people in art.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} This officially sanctioned art was conservative and figurative, heavily inspired by [[Greco-Roman]] art. It was often grandiose and sentimental. In terms of contents, this art should represent and convey the regime's ideals.
In 1937 in Munich, two simultaneous events demonstrated the [[Nazis]]’ views about art. One exhibition displayed art that should be eliminated (“The [[Degenerate Art Exhibition]]”), while the other promoted, by contrast, the official aesthetic (“The Great German Art Exhibition”).
In Europe, other [[totalitarian]] regimes adopted a similar stance on art and encouraged or imposed an official aesthetic, which was a form of [[Realism (arts)|Realism]]. Here Realism refers to a representational, mimetic style, and not to an art deprived of idealization. Such style was anchored in a prestigious tradition – popular, easy to understand, and thus practical for [[Propaganda in Nazi Germany|propaganda]] aims.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
It was clear in [[Stalin]]’s [[Soviet Union]], where diversity in the arts was proscribed and “[[Socialist Realism]]” was instituted as the official style. [[Modern art]] was banned as being decadent, [[bourgeois]] and elitist.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} The comparison of sculptures placed by national pavilions during the [[Exposition Internationale des Arts et Techniques dans la Vie Moderne|1937 International Exhibition]] in Paris is revealing. The exhibition was dominated by the confrontation between Germany and the Soviet Union, with their imposing pavilions facing each other.<ref>[[Dawn Adès]] (et al.), ''Art and Power: Europe under the Dictators, 1930-1945'', London: The South Bank Centre, 1995</ref> On one side, Josef Thorak’s sculptures were displayed by the German pavilion’s entrance. And on the other, [[Vera Mukhina]]’s sculpture, ''[[Worker and Kolkhoz Woman]]'', was placed on top of the Soviet pavilion.
===Degenerate art=== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 101I-729-0001-23, Italien, Überführung von Kunstschätzen.jpg|thumb|German soldiers of the [[Hermann Göring Division]] posing near the main entrance of [[Palazzo Venezia]] showing a painting taken from the National Museum of Naples Picture Gallery]] [[File:Ausstellung entartete kunst 1937.jpg|thumb|[[Joseph Goebbels]] at the [[Degenerate Art Exhibition]]]] {{Main article|Degenerate Art}} {{See also|Nazi Plunder}} The term “degenerate” was used in connection with the idea that modern artists and their art were compromising the purity of the [[Racial policy of Nazi Germany|German race]]. They were presented as elements of “racial impurity,” “parasites,” causing a deterioration of German society.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} These decadent and “degenerate” forces had to be eradicated. Cultural actors who were labelled “un-German” by the regime were persecuted: they were fired from their teaching positions, artworks were removed from museums, books were burnt.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} All artists who did not fall in line with the party's ideology (above all [[Jewish]] and [[Communist]] artists) were “un-German.”
The [[Degenerate Art Exhibition]] (Munich, 19 July-30 Nov. 1937) was made out of works confiscated in German museums. The works were placed in unflattering ways, with derogatory comments and slogans painted around them (“Nature as seen by sick minds”, “Deliberate sabotage of national defense”...). The aim was to convince visitors that modern art was an attack on the German people. Mostly, these works of art were [[Expressionist]], abstract or made by Jewish and [[Leftist]] artists. The exhibition was displayed in several German and Austrian cities. Subsequently, most of the artworks were either [[art destruction|destroyed]] or sold.]]
Modern art could not fall in line with the Nazi values and taste for several reasons: * its constant innovation and change * its independency and freedom * its cosmopolitanism and reticence to profess any type of nationalist allegiance * its ambiguity and its lack of easily understandable and definitive meaning * its rejection and deconstruction of the mimetic tradition of representation{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
France was occupied by Nazi Germany from 22 June 1940 until early May 1945. An occupying power endeavours to normalise life as far as is possible since this optimises the maintenance of order and minimises the costs of occupation. The Germans decreed that life, including artistic life should resume as before (the war).}} There were exceptions. Jews were targeted, and their art collections confiscated. Some of this consisted of modern, [[degenerate art]] which was partly destroyed, although some was sold on the international art market. Masterpieces of European art were taken from these collectors and French museums and were sent to Germany.<ref>Lionel Richard, L’art et la guerre: Les artistes confrontés à la Seconde guerre mondiale, Paris, Flammarion, 1995, chapter 5, « Butins de guerre » ; Laurence Bertand-Dorléac, ''Art of the Defeat. France 1940-1944'', transl. from French by Jane Mary Todd, Getty Research Institute, 2008, p. 12 and following</ref> Known political opponents were also excluded and overtly political art was forbidden.
==Persecuted artists== {{See also|Degenerate Art#Fate of the artists and their work}} During the rise of Nazism, some artists had expressed their opposition. Following the establishment of the [[Third Reich]], modern artists and those of Jewish ancestry were classed as [[Degenerate art|degenerate]]. Any Jewish artists, or artists who were known opponents to the regime, were liable to imprisonment unless they conformed with the authorities’ view of what was "acceptable" in art. These artists were all in danger. Among those who chose to stay in Germany, some retreated into an “inner exile”, or “inner emigration"<ref>Lionel Richard, ''Le nazisme et la culture'', éditions Complexe, 2006, p. 133</ref> (“Innere Emigration”).
Artists had the choice of collaborating or resisting. But most people in such a predicament will normally find a middle way. Resistance was dangerous and unlikely to escape fierce punishment and while collaboration offered an easier path principled objection to it was a strong deterrent to many if not most. The other options were withdrawal, finding refuge abroad or, for many, to take the pragmatic course by simply continuing to work within the new restrictions. Hence artistic life and expression appeared light, carefree and frivolous, but was also lively.<ref>Cf. Alan Riding, ''And the Show Went On: Cultural Life in Nazi-Occupied Paris'', Alfred A. Knopf, 2010; Laurence Bertand-Dorléac, ''Art of the Defeat. France 1940-1944'', transl. from French by Jane Mary Todd, Getty Research Institute, 2008</ref>
===Exiled artists=== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-05929, Berlin, KPD-Plakat zu den Reichstagswahlen.jpg|thumb|''5 Fingers Has The Hand'' by John Heartfield, 1928]] The German artist [[John Heartfield]] (who had been part of [[Dada]] Berlin) is an example of an artist who expressed opposition. While Hitler's popularity was growing in Germany, he consistently produced photomontages that denounced the future dictator and his party. Most of them were published in ''[[Arbeiter-Illustrierte-Zeitung]]'' [''AIZ'', Workers' Illustrated Newspaper], and a lot of them appeared on the cover. His artworks were like visual weapons against Nazism, a counter-power. In them, he subverted Hitler's figure and [[Nazi symbols]]. Through powerful visual juxtapositions, he revealed Nazism manipulations and contradictions, and showed the truth about them. As soon as Hitler [[Adolf Hitler's rise to power|came to power]] in 1933, Heartfield had to flee, finding refuge first in Prague and then in the UK.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
[[Otto Dix]] had been labelled as a “degenerate” artist. His works were removed from museums, he was fired from his teaching position, and he was forbidden to create anything political as well as to exhibit. He moved to the countryside and painted landscapes for the duration of the war.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
Many artists chose to leave Germany. But their exile did not secure their position in the art world abroad. Their personal and artistic security depended on the laws and attitude of the country of exile. Some sought collaboration with others in exile, forming groups to exhibit, such as the Free German League of Culture founded in 1938 in London.<ref>“Arts in Exile”, virtual exhibition, the German Exile Archive 1933-1945 of the German National Library, 2012: http://kuenste-im-exil.de/KIE/Content/EN/Topics/freier-deutscher-kulturbund-gro%C3%9Fbritannien-en.html (last retrieved: 04-04-2015)</ref> One of their goals was to show that German culture and art were not to be equated with the cultural expressions sanctioned and produced by the Nazi regime.
Other artists went their own way, independently, often choosing apolitical subjects and sometimes refusing to participate in political events.<ref>Stéphanie Barron (ed.), ''Exiles + Emigrés, The Flight of European Artists from Hitler'', exh. cat., Los Angeles County Museum of Art; New York: Harry N. Abrams, 1997</ref> They considered art as a completely autonomous activity that should not be submitted to a political cause. On the contrary, someone like [[Oskar Kokoschka]], who had until then rejected the idea that art should be useful and serve a cause, got involved in these groups when he emigrated to London in 1938. He created a series of political allegories, i.e. paintings in which he made comments on war politics.<ref>Cf. Stéphanie Barron (ed.), ''Exiles + Emigrés, The Flight of European Artists from Hitler'', exh. cat., Los Angeles County Museum of Art, New York: Harry N. Abrams, 1997; Melody A. Maxted, “Envisioning Kokoschka: Considering the Artist’s Political Allegories, 1939-1954”, in ''Montage'', 2 (2008): 87-97</ref>
===Artists in internment camps=== Once the war had commenced, everyone of Austro-German extraction was considered to be a security risk in Britain and became an [[enemy alien]]. They were interned in 1940, in camps on the Isle of Man. In Britain, however, there was considerable concern that many who had opposed the Nazi regime and escaped with their lives were now in detention in poor conditions. This led to a form of re-classification that led to many early releases in 1940, and by 1942 most of the internees had been released.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
Inside the camps, some of the inmates were artists, musicians, and other intelligentsia, and they rebuilt as much cultural life as they could within the constraints of their imprisonment: the giving of lectures and concerts and the creation of artworks from materials like charcoal from burnt twigs, dyes from plants and the use of lino and newspaper. They also received materials from the artistic community in Britain.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
[[Heinz Kiwitz]] went into exile in 1937 after his release from imprisonment in [[Kemna concentration camp|Kemna]] and [[Emslandlager|Börgermoor concentration camps]]. [[Max Ernst]] exiled to the United States in 1941.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
In France, Austro-German citizens also became “enemy aliens” at the outbreak of war and were sent in internment camps. The [[Camp des Milles]], near Aix-en-Provence, where German artists such as Max Ernst and [[Hans Bellmer]] were imprisoned, was famous for its artistic life.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} As France was invaded, the situation of exiled German artists got more complicated and dangerous. They risked deportation, forced labour and extermination in the case of Jewish artists, both in occupied France and in the Vichy Republic. Most chose to emigrate further while others went into hiding.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
In the US, citizens of Japanese extraction also faced [[Internment of Japanese Americans|internment]] in very poor living conditions and with little sympathy for their plight throughout the period of hostilities and beyond.
==World War II art==
===Protest art===
Those who wished to overtly oppose the Nazis in their art either worked abroad (for example, [[André Masson]]) or clandestinely, as part of the resistance movement (such as André Fougeron). In the public space, resistance took on more symbolic forms. A group known as 'Jeunes peintres de tradition française' exhibited in Paris for the first time in 1941. The works they produced during the period were characterised by semi-abstract art and bright colours, which they considered as a form of resistance to the Nazis.<ref>Lionel Richard, ''L’art et la guerre: Les artistes confrontés à la Seconde guerre mondiale'', Paris, Flammarion, 1995, p. 190</ref> Other supposedly non-political works were ambiguous – they observed the hardships of life in France without apportioning blame. [[Pablo Picasso|Picasso]], who had stayed in Paris, painted but refused to exhibit. He did not paint the war or anything openly political, but he said that the war was in his pictures.<ref>Picasso, in Peter D. Whitney, “Picasso is Safe”, ''San Francisco Chronicle'', 3 Sept. 1944, quoted by M. Bohm-Duchen, ''Art and the Second World War'', Farnham: Lund Humphries, 2013, p. 112</ref>
Modern art became the bearer of liberal values, as opposed to the reactionary artistic preferences of the totalitarian regimes. Artistic choices embodied different positions in the ongoing ideological battle. Placing Alberto Sánchez Pérez's abstract sculpture,<ref>See Dawn Ades (et al.), ''Art and Power: Europe under the Dictators, 1930-1945'', London: The South Bank Centre, 1995</ref> ''The Spanish people have a path that leads to a star'' (1937), at the entrance of the pavilion of the Spanish Republic was a political statement. So was commissioning modern artists to create works of art for this pavilion. [[Pablo Picasso]] showed two works: a pair of etchings entitled ''[[The Dream and Lie of Franco]]'', 1937, and his monumental painting, [[Guernica (Picasso)|Guernica]], 1937. [[Joan Miró]] painted a huge mural entitled ''Catalan Peasant in Revolt'' (aka [[The Reaper (Miró painting)|The Reaper]], destroyed), and he did a poster entitled “Aidez l’Espagne” (Help Spain), meant to support the Republicans’ cause. The American artist [[Alexander Calder]] created the abstract sculpture ''[[Mercury Fountain]]'' (1937). The involvement of a non-Spanish artist was also an important statement in an era dominated by the rise of nationalism, both in democratic and totalitarian regimes.
Even in democracies, voices called for a return to a more representational style. For instance, some criticized the central place given to Picasso's [[Guernica (Picasso)|Guernica]] because it was not explicit enough in its denunciation and was too complex.<ref>Monica Bohm-Duchen, ''Art and the Second World War'', Farnham: Lund Humphries, 2013, p. 25. Robin A. Greeley, S''urrealism and the Spanish Civil War'', New Haven: Yale University Press, 2006, p. 241</ref> They would have preferred that the focus be placed on paintings such as [[Horacio Ferrer]]’s ''Madrid 1937 (Black Planes)'', from 1937. Its “message” was much clearer and – as a consequence – it functioned better as a political statement.
When they wanted to support the democratic cause and protest against [[Fascism]] and [[dictators]], artists were often encouraged to put aside their modernist style and express themselves in a more realist (i.e. representational) style. For instance, [[Josep Renau]], the Republican Government's director general of Fine Arts, said in 1937: “The poster maker, as an artist, knows a disciplined freedom, a freedom conditioned by objective demands, external to his individual will. Thus for the poster artist the simple question of expressing his own sensibility and emotion is neither legitimate nor practically realizable, if not in the service of an objective goal.<ref>Josep Renau, quoted by M. Bohm-Duchen, ''Art and the Second World War'', Farnham: Lund Humphries, 2013, p. 18</ref>” And the French author, [[Louis Aragon]], declared in 1936: “For artists as for every person who feels like a spokesperson for a new humanity, the Spanish flames and blood put [[Realism (arts)|Realism]] on the agenda.<ref>Louis Aragon, in ''La Commune'', 1936, quoted by [[Lionel Richard]], ''L’art et la guerre: Les artistes confrontés à la Seconde guerre mondiale'', Paris, Flammarion, 1995 (transl. from French)</ref>” In other words, the artist's political engagement required a submission of the work's artistic aspects to the expression of the political content.
The series ''The Year of Peril'', created in [[1942 in art|1942]] by the American artist [[Thomas Hart Benton (painter)|Thomas Hart Benton]], illustrates how the boundary between art and propaganda can be blurred by such a stance. Produced as a reaction to the bombing of [[Pearl Harbor]] by the [[Imperial Japanese Army|Japanese army]] in 1941, the series portrayed the threat posed to the U.S. by Nazism and Fascism in an expressive but representational style. The message is clearly and powerfully delivered. These images were massively reproduced and disseminated in order to contribute to raise support for the U.S. involvement in World War II.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
Thus, there can be troubling affinities between Allied politically-engaged art and fascist and totalitarian art when in both cases art and artists are used to create “persuasive images”, i.e. visual propaganda. Such a conception of political art was problematic for many modern artists as modernism was precisely defined by its autonomy from anything non-artistic. For some, absolute artistic freedom – and thus freedom from the requirement of having a clear, stable, and easily decipherable meaning – should have been what symbolised the liberal and progressive values and spirit of democracies.<ref>M. Bohm-Duchen, ''Art and the Second World War'', Farnham: Lund Humphries, 2013, p. 87</ref>
===Political art=== [[File:Shelter Experiments, near Woburn, Bedfordshire (Art. IWM ART LD 3859).jpg|thumb|''Shelter Experiments, near Woburn, Bedfordshire'' by [[John Piper (artist)|John Piper]], 1943]] [[File:The City A fallen lift shaft (1941) (Art.IWM ART LD 893).jpg|thumb|''The City A fallen lift shaft'' by [[Graham Sutherland]], 1941]] Britain was also subject to political differences during the 1930s but did not suffer repression nor civil war as elsewhere, and could enter World War II with a justifiable sense of defending freedom and democracy. Art had similarly followed the free expression at the heart of modernism, but political appropriation was already sought [as in the left-wing [[Artists’ International Association]] founded in 1933]. With the outbreak of war came official recognition of art's use as propaganda. However, in Britain, political promotion did not include the persecution of artistic freedom in general.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
In 1939, the [[War Artists Advisory Committee]] (WAAC) was founded under the aegis of the British Ministry of Information, with the remit to list and select artists qualified to record the war and pursue other war purposes. Artists were thought to have special skills useful to a country at war: they could interpret and express the essence of wartime experiences and create images that promoted the country's culture and values. Not the least of these was artists’ freedom to choose the subjects and style of their art.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} A significant influence was the choice of Sir [[Kenneth Clark]] as instigator and director of WAAC, as he believed that the first duty of an artist was to produce good works of art that would bring international renown. And he believed the second duty was to produce images through which a country presents itself to the world, and a record of war more expressive than a camera may give.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} Important to this was the exhibition of Britain at War at [[New York Museum of Modern Art|Museum of Modern Art]] in New York in 1941 (22 May to 2 September).{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
This initiative also provided support for British artists when the world seemed to be sinking into barbarism. But it was not without intentions and constraints, and some works were rejected or censored. Accurate representations were required and abstract art, as it did not deliver a clear message, was avoided. Some depictions could be too realistic and were censored because they revealed sensitive information or would have scared people – and maintaining the nation's morale was vital. No foreign artists were admitted to the programme, a great sorrow to many who had fled to Britain from persecution elsewhere.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
Despite these restrictions, the work commissioned was illustrative, non-bombastic, and often of great distinction thanks to established artists such as [[Paul Nash (artist)|Paul Nash]], [[John Piper (artist)|John Piper]], [[Henry Moore]], [[Graham Sutherland]] and [[Stanley Spencer]].
===Holocaust art=== {{Main article|The Holocaust in popular culture}} Many works of art and images were created by detainees in ghettos and in concentration and extermination camps. They form a large body of images. Most of them were small and fragile, many were destroyed and lost. The large majority of these images were created clandestinely because such a creative activity was forbidden and could have resulted in a death sentence. Yet, many inmates found materials and transgressed the rules in order to create.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
Their motives for doing so were multiple but they all seem to have been linked to a survival instinct and self-preservation.<ref>Lionel Richard, ''L’art et la guerre: Les artistes confrontés à la Seconde guerre mondiale'', Paris, Flammarion, 1995, p. 216: for some internees, art had a « live-saving function » (transl. from French)</ref> Art could be a distraction and an escape from the horrors of the present. Distancing oneself (by depicting imaginary scenes or by taking on the role of the observer) was a way to keep some sanity. Doing drawings could also be a way to barter and thus to increase one's chances of survival in the camp or ghetto. Moreover, by creating visual artefacts there was the hope of creating something that would survive to one's death and would live on to testify to one's existence. Some seemed to have been animated by a documentary spirit: recording what was happening to them for people beyond the fence. Finally, such a creative urge was a form of cultural resistance. When their persecutors were trying to eradicate every bit of their humanity, artistic creation and testimony were ways to reclaim it, to preserve and cultivate it.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
In terms of subject matters, the images created in concentration and extermination camps are characterised by their determination to enhance the detainees’ dignity and individuality.<ref>M. Bohm-Duchen, ''Art and the Second World War'', Farnham: Lund Humphries, 2013, p. 196</ref> This is probably the most visible in the numerous portraits that were done. Whereas the Nazi extermination machine aimed at dehumanising the internees, creating “faceless” beings, clandestine artists would give them back their individuality. In this body of works, depictions of atrocities are not so frequent, which suggests that they might have been intentionally avoided. Rather, it is after the liberation, in the art of survivors that the most brutal and abominable aspects of concentration and extermination camps found a visual expression.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
In the face of such horrors, some artists were confronted with ethical problems and felt that representation had reached a limit. Thus, since the liberation of the camps, artists who have wanted to express the [[Holocaust]] in their art have often chosen abstraction or symbolism, thus avoided any explicit representations. A few went as far as to suggest that art itself – and not simply representational art – had reached a limit because creating an aesthetic object about the Holocaust would be, in itself, unethical, morally reprehensible.<ref>M. Bohm-Duchen, ''Art and the Second World War'', Farnham: Lund Humphries, 2013, p. 211</ref>

{{one source|date=March 2017}} [[Image:Australian College of Physical Education (logo).jpg|right]] The '''Australian College of Physical Education''' ('''ACPE''') is an independent specialist [[tertiary education]] institution in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]]. The college offers degree programmes in [[PDHPE]] teaching, [[physical education]], [[sports coaching]], [[health]] and [[physical fitness|fitness]], [[dance]] education, and [[sports management]]. The institute was founded in 1917, and is located at the [[Sydney Olympic Park]].
The college was founded in 1917 (making it the fourteenth-oldest tertiary education institution in Australia), initially as a physical education training institution for young women (the college only began admitting male students in 1971). The college's founder was Frank Stuart – a [[swordsman]], [[fencing]] instructor and physical training instructor, who had taught members of both the British and Russian Royal families, and went on to coach the Australian fencing teams for the 1950 [[Empire Games]] and the [[1952 Summer Olympics|1952 Olympic Games]]. The college was initially located within the premises of Normanhurst School in the Sydney suburb of [[Ashfield, New South Wales|Ashfield]]. It has an early connection with the Swords Club. (a connection recognised today through the college emblem), and in 1919 the club and the college were registered jointly as the ACPE and Swords Club Pty Ltd.
The college moved to new premises in [[Petersham, New South Wales|Petersham]] in 1949, and then to [[Croydon, New South Wales|Croydon]] in 1970. In 1995, the college moved into the Sydney Olympic Park at [[Homebush Bay, New South Wales|Homebush Bay]], where the [[2000 Summer Olympics|2000 Olympic Games]] were held. Students at the college regularly use the Olympic Park's facilities, such as the [[State Sports Centre|Sports Centre]], [[Sydney International Aquatic Centre|Aquatic Centre]] and [[NSW Tennis Centre|Tennis Centre]], for lectures and tutorials. Recently the College has moved to a brand new purpose built campus in Sydney Olympic Park at 10 Parkview Drive.
==Courses== The College currently offers 12 Undergraduate Degrees and 1 Post- Graduate Diploma:
* Bachelor of Applied Dance * Bachelor of Dance Education * Bachelor of Applied Fitness * Bachelor of Health & Movement * Bachelor of Education (PHE) * Bachelor of Health Science (Exercise) * Bachelor of Health Science (Fitness) * Bachelor of Health Science (Sport) * Bachelor of Health Science (Community Health) * Bachelor of Health Science (Dance) * Bachelor of Sports Business (Leadership) * Bachelor of Sports Coaching and Administration * Graduate Diploma of Sports Administration

[[File:M. exilis skeletal.png|thumb|upright=1.7|The [[pygmy mammoth]] is an example of [[insular dwarfism]], a case of [[Foster's rule]], its unusually small body size an adaptation to the limited resources of its island home.]]
A '''biological rule''' or '''biological law''' is a generalized [[law (science)|law]], [[principle]], or [[rule of thumb]] formulated to describe patterns observed in living organisms. Biological rules and laws are often developed as succinct, broadly applicable ways to explain complex phenomena or salient observations about the [[ecology]] and [[biogeography|biogeographical]] distributions of plant and animal [[species]] around the world, though they have been proposed for or extended to all types of organisms. Many of these regularities of ecology and biogeography are named after the biologists who first described them.<ref name="Jørgensen2002">{{cite journal |last1=Jørgensen |first1=Sven Erik |title=Explanation of ecological rules and observation by application of ecosystem theory and ecological models|journal=Ecological Modelling |volume=158 |issue=3 |year=2002 |pages=241–248 |doi=10.1016/S0304-3800(02)00236-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Allee |first=W.C. |last2=Schmidt |first2=K.P. |date=1951 |title=Ecological Animal Geography |edition=2nd |pages=457, 460–472}}</ref>
From the birth of their science, biologists have sought to explain apparent regularities in observational data. In [[Aristotle's biology|his biology]], [[Aristotle]] inferred rules governing differences between live-bearing [[tetrapod]]s (in modern terms, terrestrial placental [[mammal]]s). Among his rules were that [[brood size]] decreases with adult body mass, while [[life expectancy|lifespan]] increases with [[gestation period]] and with body mass, and [[fecundity]] decreases with lifespan. Thus, for example, elephants have smaller and fewer broods than mice, but longer lifespan and gestation.<ref>{{cite book |last=Leroi |first=Armand Marie |authorlink=Armand Marie Leroi |title=The Lagoon: How Aristotle Invented Science |titlelink=Aristotle's Lagoon |publisher=Bloomsbury |date=2014 |isbn=978-1-4088-3622-4 |page=408}}</ref> Rules like these concisely organized the sum of knowledge obtained by early scientific measurements of the natural world, and could be used as [[scientific model|models]] to predict future observations. Among the earliest biological rules in modern times are those of [[Karl Ernst von Baer]] (from 1828 onwards) on [[embryogenesis|embryonic development]],<ref name=Lovtrup/> and of [[Constantin Wilhelm Lambert Gloger]] on animal pigmentation, in 1833.<ref name=Gloger/> There is some [[scepticism]] among biogeographers about the usefulness of general rules. For example, J.C. Briggs, in his 1987 book ''Biogeography and Plate Tectonics'', comments that while [[Willi Hennig]]'s rules on [[cladistics]] "have generally been helpful", his progression rule is "suspect".<ref name="Briggs1987">{{cite book |last=Briggs |first=J.C. |title=Biogeography and Plate Tectonics |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vCNG2e5K-YgC&pg=PA11 |year=1987 |publisher=Elsevier |isbn=978-0-08-086851-6 |page=11}}</ref>
==List of biological rules== [[File:Bergmann's Rule.svg|thumb|Bergmann's rule states that body mass increases with colder climate, as here in Swedish moose.<ref name="Sand1995">{{Cite journal | doi=10.1007/BF00341355 | title=Geographical and latitudinal variation in growth patterns and adult body size of Swedish moose (''Alces alces'') | journal=[[Oecologia]] | volume=102 | issue=4 | pages=433–442 | date=June 1995 | last1=Sand | first1=Håkan K. | last2=Cederlund | first2=Göran R. | last3=Danell | first3=Kjell |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2FBF00341355 |subscription=yes |bibcode=1995Oecol.102..433S }}</ref>]]
* '''[[Allen's rule]]''' states that the body shapes and proportions of endotherms vary by climatic temperature by either minimizing exposed surface area to minimize heat loss in cold climates or maximizing exposed surface area to maximize heat loss in hot climates. It is named after [[Joel Asaph Allen]] who described it in 1877.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Joel Asaph |last=Allen |title=The influence of Physical conditions in the genesis of species |journal=Radical Review |year=1877 |volume=1 |pages=108–140 |url=http://people.wku.edu/charles.smith/biogeog/ALLE1877.htm}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=Barry Holstun |last=Lopez |year=1986 |title=Arctic Dreams: Imagination and Desire in a Northern Landscape |publisher=Scribner |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y-WxJYMD5HsC |isbn=0-684-18578-4}}</ref> * '''[[Bergmann's rule]]''' states that within a broadly distributed taxonomic [[clade]], populations and species of larger size are found in colder environments, and species of smaller size are found in warmer regions. It applies with exceptions to many mammals and birds. It was named after [[Carl Bergmann (anatomist)|Carl Bergmann]] who described it in 1847.<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Miguel Á. |last1=Olalla-Tárraga |first2=Miguel Á. |last2=Rodríguez |first3=Bradford A. |last3=Hawkins |year=2006 |title=Broad-scale patterns of body size in squamate reptiles of Europe and North America |journal=[[Journal of Biogeography]] |volume=33 |issue=5 |pages=781–793 |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2699.2006.01435.x |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/enhanced/doi/10.1111/j.1365-2699.2006.01435.x/}}</ref><ref name="Timofeev2001">{{cite journal | last=Timofeev | first=S. F. | title=Bergmann’s Principle and Deep-Water Gigantism in Marine Crustaceans | journal=Biology Bulletin (Russian version, Izvestiya Akademii Nauk, Seriya Biologicheskaya) | volume=28 | issue=6 | pages=646–650 (Russian version, 764–768) | date=2001 | url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/w40861j17433662t/ | doi=10.1023/A:1012336823275 | subscription=yes | accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref><ref name="Meiri2003">{{Cite journal | doi=10.1046/j.1365-2699.2003.00837.x | title=On the validity of Bergmann's rule | journal=Journal of Biogeography | volume=30 | issue=3 | pages=331–351 | date=2003-03-20 | last1=Meiri | first1=S. | last2=Dayan | first2=T. | url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/enhanced/doi/10.1046/j.1365-2699.2003.00837.x/ | subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name="Ashton2000">{{cite journal | jstor=10.1086/303400 | title=Is Bergmann's Rule Valid for Mammals? | date=October 2000 | first1=Kyle G. | last1=Ashton | last2=Tracy | first2=Mark C. | last3=Queiroz | first3=Alan de | journal=[[The American Naturalist]] | volume=156 | issue=4 | pages=390–415 | doi=10.1086/303400}}</ref><ref name="Millien2006">{{cite journal | title=Ecotypic variation in the context of global climate change: Revisiting the rules | first1=Virginie | last1=Millien | last2=Lyons | first2=S. Kathleen | last3=Olson | first3=Link |display-authors=etal | journal=[[Ecology Letters]] | date=May 23, 2006 | volume=9 | issue=7 | pages=853–869 | doi=10.1111/j.1461-0248.2006.00928.x |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1461-0248.2006.00928.x/epdf}}</ref> * '''[[Cope's rule]]''' states that animal population [[Lineage (evolution)|lineages]] tend to increase in body size over evolutionary time. The rule is named for the palaeontologist [[Edward Drinker Cope]].<ref>{{cite journal | last=Rensch | first=B. | authorlink=Bernhard Rensch | title=Histological Changes Correlated with Evolutionary Changes of Body Size | journal=[[Evolution (journal)|Evolution]] | volume=2 | issue=3 | pages=218–230 | date=September 1948 | jstor=2405381 | doi=10.2307/2405381}}</ref><ref name="Stanley_1973">{{cite journal | last=Stanley | first=S. M. | authorlink=Steven M. Stanley | title=An Explanation for Cope's Rule | journal=[[Evolution (journal)|Evolution]] | volume=27 | issue=1 | pages=1–26 | date=March 1973 | jstor=2407115 | doi=10.2307/2407115}}</ref> * '''[[Deep-sea gigantism]]''', noted in 1880 by [[Henry Nottidge Moseley]],<ref name="DeepSeaNews">{{cite web |author=McClain, Craig<!--Executive Director of the Lousiana University Marine Consortium--> |title=Why isn’t the Giant Isopod larger? |url=http://www.deepseanews.com/2015/01/why-isnt-the-giant-isopod-larger/ |website=Deep Sea News |accessdate=1 March 2018}}</ref> states that deep-sea animals are larger than their shallow-water counterparts. In the case of marine [[crustacean]]s, it has been proposed that the increase in size with depth occurs for the same reason as the increase in size with [[latitude]] (Bergmann's rule): both trends involve increasing size with decreasing temperature.<ref name="Timofeev">{{cite journal | last=Timofeev | first=S. F. | title=Bergmann's Principle and Deep-Water Gigantism in Marine Crustaceans | journal=Biology Bulletin (Russian version, Izvestiya Akademii Nauk, Seriya Biologicheskaya) | volume=28 | issue=6 | pages=646–650 (Russian version, 764–768)| year=2001 | url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/w40861j17433662t/ | doi=10.1023/A:1012336823275}}</ref>[[File:Dollo's law of irreversibility.svg|thumb|[[Dollo's law of irreversibility]] asserts that once an organism has [[evolution|evolved]] in a certain way, it will not return exactly to a previous form.]] * '''[[Dollo's law of irreversibility]]''', proposed in 1893<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Dollo | first1=Louis |authorlink=Louis Dollo | year=1893 | title=Les lois de l'évolution | url=http://www.paleoglot.net/files/Dollo_93.pdf | journal=Bull. Soc. Belge Geol. Pal. Hydr | volume=VII | pages=164–166 }}</ref> by [[France|French]]-born [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[paleontology|paleontologist]] [[Louis Dollo]] states that "an organism never returns exactly to a former state, even if it finds itself placed in conditions of existence identical to those in which it has previously lived ... it always keeps some trace of the intermediate stages through which it has passed."<ref>{{Cite journal| last=Gould | first=Stephen J. | authorlink=Stephen Jay Gould | year=1970 | title=Dollo on Dollo's law: irreversibility and the status of evolutionary laws| journal=Journal of the History of Biology| volume=3 | pages=189–212}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi=10.1111/j.1558-5646.2008.00505.x | pmid=18764918 | volume=62 | issue=11 | pages=2727–2741 | last=Goldberg | first=Emma E. |author2=Boris Igić | title=On phylogenetic tests of irreversible evolution | journal=Evolution | year=2008 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi=10.1016/j.tree.2008.06.013 | pmid=18814933 | volume=23 | issue=11 | pages=602–609 | last=Collin | first=Rachel |author2=Maria Pia Miglietta | title=Reversing opinions on Dollo's Law | journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution| year=2008}}</ref> * '''[[Eichler's rule]]''' states that the taxonomic diversity of parasites co-varies with the diversity of their hosts. It was observed in 1942 by Wolfdietrich Eichler, and is named for him.<ref name=Eichler1942>{{cite journal |last=Eichler |first=Wolfdietrich |title=Die Entfaltungsregel und andere Gesetzmäßigkeiten in den parasitogenetischen Beziehungen der Mallophagen und anderer ständiger Parasiten zu ihren Wirten|journal=[[Zoologischer Anzeiger]] |year=1942 |volume=136 |pages=77–83 |url=http://phthiraptera.info/sites/phthiraptera.info/files/39548.pdf}}</ref><ref name=Klassen>{{cite journal |last=Klassen |first=G. J. |title=Coevolution: a history of the macroevolutionary approach to studying host-parasite associations |journal=Journal of Parasitology |year=1992 |volume=78 |issue=4 |pages=573–87 |pmid=1635016 |doi=10.2307/3283532}}</ref><ref name=Vas>{{cite journal |last=Vas |first=Z. |author2=Csorba, G. |author3=Rozsa, L. |title=Evolutionary co-variation of host and parasite diversity – the first test of Eichler’s rule using parasitic lice (Insecta: Phthiraptera) |journal=Parasitology Research |year=2012 |volume=111 |pages=393–401 |doi=10.1007/s00436-012-2850-9 |url=http://www.zoologia.hu/list/Vas_Csorba_Rozsa_2012.pdf}}</ref>[[File:Bombus bohemicus - Keila.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Emery's rule]] states that insect [[social parasitism (biology)|social parasites]] like [[Psithyrus|cuckoo bumblebees]] choose closely-related hosts, in this case other [[bumblebee]]s.]] * '''[[Emery's rule]]''', noticed by [[Carlo Emery]], states that insect [[social parasitism (biology)|social parasites]] are often closely related to their hosts, such as being in the same genus.<ref name="RD">{{cite web|url=http://www.nature.com/scitable/knowledge/library/social-parasitism-in-ants-13256421 |title=Social Parasitism in Ants | author=Richard Deslippe | publisher=Nature Education Knowledge | year=2010 |accessdate=2010-10-29| quote=In 1909, the taxonomist Carlo Emery made an important generalization, now known as Emery’s rule, which states that social parasites and their hosts share common ancestry and hence are closely related to each other (Emery 1909).}}</ref><ref name="Emery_1909">{{cite journal |author=Emery, Carlo |authorlink=Carlo Emery |date=1909 |title=Über den Ursprung der dulotischen, parasitischen und myrmekophilen Ameisen |language=German |journal=Biologisches Centralblatt |volume=29 |pages=352–362}}</ref> * '''[[Foster's rule]]''', the '''island rule''', or the '''island effect''' states that members of a species get smaller or bigger depending on the resources available in the environment.<ref>Juan Luis Arsuaga, Andy Klatt, ''The Neanderthal's Necklace: In Search of the First Thinkers'', Thunder's Mouth Press, 2004, {{ISBN|1-56858-303-6}}, {{ISBN|978-1-56858-303-7}}, p. 199.</ref><ref>Jean-Baptiste de Panafieu, Patrick Gries, ''Evolution'', Seven Stories Press, 2007, {{ISBN|1-58322-784-9}}, {{ISBN|978-1-58322-784-8}}, p 42.</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Lomolino |first1=Mark V. |title=Body Size of Mammals on Islands: The Island Rule Reexamined |journal=The American Naturalist |date=February 1985 |volume=125 |issue=2 |pages=310–316 |jstor=2461638 |doi=10.1086/284343}}</ref> The rule was first stated by J. Bristol Foster in 1964 in the journal ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'', in an article titled "The evolution of mammals on islands".<ref>{{cite journal | last=Foster | first=J.B. | year=1964 | title=The evolution of mammals on islands | journal=Nature | volume=202 | issue=4929 | pages=234–235 | doi=10.1038/202234a0 | bibcode=1964Natur.202..234F}}</ref> * '''[[Competitive exclusion principle|Gause's law]]''' or the '''competitive exclusion principle''', named for [[Georgy Gause]], states that two species competing for the same resource cannot coexist at constant population values. The competition leads either to the extinction of the weaker competitor or to an [[evolution]]ary or behavioral shift toward a different [[ecological niche]].<ref name=hardin60>{{cite journal |author=Hardin, Garrett |title=The competitive exclusion principle |journal=Science |volume=131 |pages=1292–1297 |issue=3409 |year=1960 |url=http://www.esf.edu/efb/schulz/seminars/hardin.pdf |format=PDF |doi=10.1126/science.131.3409.1292 |pmid=14399717}}</ref> * '''[[Gloger's rule]]''' states that within a species of [[Warm-blooded|endotherms]], more heavily [[biological pigment|pigmented]] forms tend to be found in more [[humid]] environments, e.g. near the [[equator]]. It was named after the zoologist [[Constantin Wilhelm Lambert Gloger]], who described it in 1833.<ref name=Gloger>{{cite book | last=Gloger| first=Constantin Wilhelm Lambert| authorlink=Constantin Wilhelm Lambert Gloger | year=1833| title=Das Abändern der Vögel durch Einfluss des Klimas|trans-title=The Evolution of Birds Through the Impact of Climate| publisher=[[August Schulz]]| location=Breslau| chapter=5. Abänderungsweise der einzelnen, einer Veränderung durch das Klima unterworfenen Farben| pages=11–24 | isbn=978-3-8364-2744-9| oclc=166097356| url=https://books.google.com/?id=IwwAAAAAQAAJ | chapterurl=https://books.google.com/?id=IwwAAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA11| language=German}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| last=Zink| first=R.M.| last2=Remsen| first2=J.V.| year=1986| title=Evolutionary processes and patterns of geographic variation in birds| journal=[[Current Ornithology (journal)|Current Ornithology]]| volume=4| pages=1–69}}</ref> * '''[[Haldane's rule]]''' states that if in a [[species]] [[hybrid (biology)|hybrid]] only one sex is [[Sterility (physiology)|sterile]], that sex is usually the [[heterogametic sex]]. The heterogametic sex is the one with two different sex chromosomes; in mammals, this is the male, with XY chromosomes. It is named after [[J.B.S. Haldane]].<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Turelli, M. |author2=Orr, H. Allen |author2link=H. Allen Orr |pmc=1206564 |title=The Dominance Theory of Haldane's Rule |journal=[[Genetics (journal)|Genetics]] |date=May 1995 |volume=140 |issue=1 |pages=389–402}}</ref> * '''[[Hamilton's rule]]''' states that [[gene]]s should increase in frequency when the relatedness of a recipient to an actor, multiplied by the benefit to the recipient, exceeds the reproductive cost to the actor. This is a prediction from the theory of [[kin selection]] formulated by [[W. D. Hamilton]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Queller | first1=D.C. | last2=Strassman | first2=J.E. | year=2002 | title=Quick Guide: Kin Selection | url=http://www.ruf.rice.edu/%7Eevolve/pdf/20002001/CurBio2002_12_R832.pdf | journal=[[Current Biology]] | volume=12 | issue=24 | page=R832 | doi=10.1016/s0960-9822(02)01344-1}}</ref> * '''[[Harrison's rule]]''' states that parasite body sizes co-vary with those of their hosts. He proposed the rule for [[louse|lice]],<ref name=Harrison_1915>{{cite journal | last=Harrison| first=Launcelot| title=Mallophaga from Apteryx, and their significance; with a note on the genus Rallicola | journal=[[Parasitology]] | year=1915 | volume=8 | pages=88–100 | url=http://www.phthiraptera.info/Publications/0182.pdf }}</ref> but later authors have shown that it works equally well for many other groups of parasite including barnacles, nematodes,<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Morand | first1=S.| last2=Legendre | first2=P.| last3=Gardner | first3=SL| last4=Hugot | first4=JP| title=Body size evolution of oxyurid (Nematoda) parasites: the role of hosts | journal=[[Oecologia]] | year=1996| volume=107| pages=274–282 | url=https://digitalcommons.unl.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=https://scholar.google.com/&httpsredir=1&article=1082&context=parasitologyfacpubs}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1=Morand | first1=S.| last2=Sorci | first2=G.| title=Determinants of life-history evolution in nematodes | journal=[[Parasitology Today]] | year=1998| volume=14| pages=193–196 |url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/academia.edu.documents/42637076/Determinants_of_Life-history_Evolution_i20160212-1576-1hyxt2f.pdf?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAIWOWYYGZ2Y53UL3A&Expires=1522433278&Signature=HpOSTvmt%2F3St5u2%2FMJuahK8ICCM%3D&response-content-disposition=inline%3B%20filename%3DDeterminants_of_life-history_evolution_i.pdf}}</ref> fleas, flies, mites, and ticks, and for the analogous case of small herbivores on large plants.<ref name=Harveyetal>{{cite journal | last1=Harvey | first1=P.H. | last2=Keymer | first2=A.E. | title=Comparing life histories using phylogenies | journal=[[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B]]| year=1991| volume=332 | pages=31–39}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1=Morand | first1=S.| last2=Hafner | first2=M.S. | last3=Page| first3=R.D.M. | last4=Reed| first4=D.L.| title=Comparative body size relationships in pocket gophers and their chewing lice | journal=[[Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society]] | year=2000| volume=70 | pages=239–249 | url=http://www.phthiraptera.info/Publications/37965.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1=Johnson | first1=K.P.| last2=Bush| first2=S.E.| last3=Clayton | first3=D.H.| title=Correlated evolution of host and parasite body size: tests of Harrison’s rule using birds and lice | journal=[[Evolution]] | year=2005| volume=59 | pages=1744–1753 |url=http://www.phthiraptera.info/Publications/46181.pdf}}</ref> * '''[[Hennig's progression rule]]''' states that when considering a group of species in [[cladistics]], the species with the most primitive characters are found within the earliest part of the area, which will be the center of origin of that group. It is named for [[Willi Hennig]], who devised the rule.<ref name=Briggs1987/><ref>{{cite web |title=Centers of Origin, Vicariance Biogeography |url=http://www.geo.arizona.edu/Antevs/ecol438/lect12.html |publisher=The University of Arizona Geosciences |accessdate=12 October 2016}}</ref> * '''[[Jordan's rule]]''' states that there is an [[inverse relationship]] between water temperature and [[meristic]] characteristics such as the number of [[fin ray]]s, vertebrae, or scale numbers, which are seen to increase with decreasing temperature. It is named after the father of American [[ichthyology]], [[David Starr Jordan]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=McDowall |first1=R. M. |title=Jordan’s and other ecogeographical rules, and the vertebral number in fishes |journal=Journal of Biogeography |date=March 2008 |volume=35 |issue=3 |pages=501–508 |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2699.2007.01823.x |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-2699.2007.01823.x/abstract}}</ref>[[File:Sykora02.jpg|thumb|[[Lack's principle]] matches clutch size to the largest number of young the parents can feed]] * '''[[Lack's principle]]''', proposed by [[David Lack]], states that "the clutch size of each species of bird has been adapted by [[natural selection]] to correspond with the largest number of young for which the parents can, on average, provide enough food".<ref name=Lack1954>{{cite book |author=Lack, David |date=1954 |title=The regulation of animal numbers |publisher=Clarendon Press}}</ref> * '''[[Rapoport's rule]]''' states that the [[latitude|latitudinal]] ranges of [[plant]]s and [[animal]]s are generally smaller at lower latitudes than at higher latitudes. It was named after [[Eduardo H. Rapoport]] by G. C. Stevens in 1989.<ref>Stevens, G. C. (1989). ''The latitudinal gradients in geographical range: how so many species co-exist in the tropics''. American Naturalist 133, 240–256.</ref> * '''[[Rensch's rule]]''' states that, across animal species within a lineage, [[sexual size dimorphism]] increases with body size when the male is the larger sex, and decreases as body size increases when the female is the larger sex. The rule applies in [[primates]], [[pinnipeds]] (seals), and [[even-toed ungulates]] (such as cattle and deer).<ref>{{cite journal |author=Fairbairn, D.J. |title=Allometry for Sexual Size Dimorphism: Pattern and Process in the Coevolution of Body Size in Males and Females |journal=Annu. Rev. Ecol. Syst. |volume=28 |issue=1 |pages=659–687 |year=1997 |doi=10.1146/annurev.ecolsys.28.1.659}}</ref> It is named after [[Bernhard Rensch]], who proposed it in 1950.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Rensch, Bernhard | authorlink=Bernhard Rensch |date=1950 |title=Die Abhängigkeit der relativen Sexualdifferenz von der Körpergrösse |journal=Bonner Zoologische Beiträge |volume=1 |pages=58–69}}</ref> * '''[[Schmalhausen's law]]''', named after [[Ivan Schmalhausen]], states that a [[population]] at the extreme limit of its tolerance in any one aspect is more vulnerable to small differences in any other aspect. Therefore, the variance of data is not simply noise interfering with the detection of so-called "main effects", but also an indicator of stressful conditions leading to greater vulnerability.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Lewontin, Richard |author1link=Richard Lewontin |author2=Levins, Richard |title=Schmalhausen's Law |journal=Capitalism, Nature, Socialism |volume=11 |issue=4 |year=2000 |pages=103–108}}</ref> * '''[[Thorson's rule]]''' states that [[benthic]] [[marine invertebrates]] at low latitudes tend to produce large numbers of eggs developing to [[pelagic]] (often planktotrophic <nowiki>[plankton-feeding]</nowiki>) and widely dispersing larvae, whereas at high latitudes such organisms tend to produce fewer and larger lecithotrophic (yolk-feeding) eggs and larger offspring, often by [[viviparity]] or [[ovoviviparity]], which are often brooded.<ref name="Thorson">Thorson, G. 1957 Bottom communities (sublittoral or shallow shelf). In "Treatise on Marine Ecology and Palaeoecology" (Ed J.W. Hedgpeth) pp. 461-534. Geological Society of America.</ref> It was named after [[Gunnar Thorson]] by S. A. Mileikovsky in 1971.<ref name="Mileikovsky">Mileikovsky, S. A. 1971. ''Types of larval development in marine bottom invertebrates, their distribution and ecological significance: a reevaluation.'' Marine Biology 19: 193-213</ref>{{Double image|right|Cambrian Trilobite Olenoides Mt. Stephen.jpg|119|FMIB 35665 Common Crayfish (Astacus fluviatilis, Male) (cropped).jpeg|100|[[Williston's law]] states that in lineages such as the [[arthropods]], limbs tend to become fewer and more specialised, as shown by the [[crayfish]] (right), whereas the more basal [[trilobite|trilobites]] had many similar legs.}} * '''[[Van Valen's law]]''' states that the probability of [[extinction]] for species and higher taxa (such as families and orders) is constant for each group over time; groups grow neither more resistant nor more vulnerable to extinction, however old their lineage is. It is named for the evolutionary biologist [[Leigh Van Valen]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Leigh Van Valen, evolutionary theorist and paleobiology pioneer, 1935-2010 |url=https://news.uchicago.edu/article/2010/10/19/leigh-van-valen-evolutionary-theorist-and-paleobiology-pioneer-1935-2010 |publisher=University of Chicago |date=20 October 2010}}</ref> * '''[[von Baer's laws (embryology)|von Baer's laws]]''', discovered by [[Karl Ernst von Baer]], state that [[embryo]]s start from a common form and develop into increasingly specialised forms, so that the diversification of embryonic form mirrors the [[tree of life (biology)|taxonomic and phylogenetic tree]]. Therefore, all animals in a phylum share a similar early embryo; animals in smaller taxa (classes, orders, families, genera, species) share later and later embryonic stages. This was in sharp contrast to the [[recapitulation theory]] of [[Johann Friedrich Meckel]] (and later of [[Ernst Haeckel]]), which claimed that embryos went through stages resembling adult organisms from successive stages of the ''[[scala naturae]]'' from supposedly lowest to highest levels of organisation.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Opitz |first1=John M. |last2=Schultka |first2=Rüdiger |last3=Göbbel |first3=Luminita |title=Meckel on developmental pathology |journal=American Journal of Medical Genetics Part A |date=2006 |volume=140A |issue=2 |pages=115–128 |doi=10.1002/ajmg.a.31043}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Garstang |first1=Walter |authorlink=Walter Garstang |title=The Theory of Recapitulation: A Critical Re-statement of the Biogenetic Law |journal=Journal of the Linnean Society of London, Zoology |date=1922|volume=35 |issue=232 |pages=81–101 |doi=10.1111/j.1096-3642.1922.tb00464.x}}</ref><ref name=Lovtrup>{{cite journal |last1=Lovtrup |first1=Soren |title=On von Baerian and Haeckelian Recapitulation |journal=Systematic Zoology |date=1978 |volume=27 |issue=3 |pages=348 |doi=10.2307/2412887}}</ref> * '''[[Williston's law]]''', first noticed by [[Samuel Wendell Williston]], states that parts in an organism tend to become reduced in number and greatly specialized in function. He had studied the dentition of vertebrates, and noted that where ancient animals had mouths with differing kinds of teeth, modern carnivores had incisors and canines specialized for tearing and cutting flesh, while modern herbivores had large molars specialized for grinding tough plant materials.<ref>{{cite book |last=Williston |first=Samuel Wendall |authorlink=Samuel Wendell Williston |title=Water Reptiles of the Past and Present |publisher=University of Chicago Press |location=Chicago |year=1914}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Use British English|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Black Gold | image = Black Gold (2006) Poster.jpg | director = Marc James Francis, Nick Francis | producer = Christopher Hird, Marc Francis, Nick Francis | writer = Marc Francis, Nick Francis | starring = Tadesse Meskela | music = Andreas Kapsalis | editing = Hugh Williams | studio = [[Speakit Films]] | released = 2006 ([[United States|USA]]) | runtime = 78 min. | language = Amharic, Oromiffa and English with English subtitles | budget = 760,000 USD<ref>{{cite news|last=Adelman |first=Jacob |url=http://archives.seattletimes.nwsource.com/cgi-bin/texis.cgi/web/vortex/display?slug=starbucksdoc28&date=20061128 |title=Anti-business films are the new muckrakers |publisher=Seattle Times |date=28 November 2006 |accessdate=20 March 2011}}</ref> }}
'''''Black Gold''''' is a 2006 documentary film that follows the efforts of an Ethiopian coffee-union manager as he travels the world to obtain a better price for his workers' [[coffee bean]]s. The film was directed and produced by Marc James Francis and Nick Francis from [[Speakit Films]], and co-produced by Christopher Hird. It premiered at the [[2006 Sundance Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.close-upfilm.com/features/regionalfilm/southeast-news-brightonatsundance.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-02-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080522132345/http://www.close-upfilm.com/features/regionalfilm/southeast-news-brightonatsundance.htm |archivedate=22 May 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Synopsis== The film focuses on the coffee growers of the [[Oromia Region]] of southern and western [[Ethiopia]], the birthplace of coffee. It follows [[Tadesse Meskela]], the General Manager of the [[Oromia Coffee Farmers Cooperative Union]], as he visits coffee-growing regions in [[Sidamo Province|Sidamo]] and Oromia (including the Kilenso Mokonisa Cooperative in the [[Bule Hora]] [[woreda]] in the [[Borena Zone]] of the Oromia Region), as well as a coffee processing center, a coffee auction house, and his union's headquarters in [[Addis Ababa]]. He also travels to England and the United States in an effort to promote Ethiopian coffee by eliminating the numerous middlemen. There is also a scene where coffee farmers pray to God for a higher price, which was filmed at the Negele Gorbitu Cooperative, located near [[Irgachefe]] in the [[Gelana Abaya|Abaya]] woreda of the Borena Zone. The Ethiopian coffee farmers speak about their lives, with one explaining that he is cutting down his coffee plants and planting ''[[khat]]'' (a plant containing [[cathinone]], an [[amphetamine]]-like stimulant) instead, due to the low price he is getting for coffee because of the explosion in the number of coffee farmers across the globe, and the comparatively higher price he can get for ''khat''.
The film also includes footage of the [[New York Board of Trade]], a [[commodity markets|commodity-trading]] floor in New York City, where the "C" international benchmark price of coffee is set each business day based on supply and demand, and explores the effects that these international prices (which by 2006 were at an all-time low) have on Ethiopian coffee growers. Other footage was shot at the first [[Starbucks]] and the [[World Barista Championship]] at the 2005 [[Specialty Coffee Association of America]] conference in Seattle; and at a café and the [[Illy]] coffee company in [[Trieste]], [[Italy]]. These scenes stand in stark contrast to the footage of the impoverished conditions faced by the Ethiopian coffee farmers and their families.
==Production== In July 2003, Nick Francis and Marc James Francis travelled to Ethiopia and started making the film. The meeting with Tadesse Meskela, the manager of Oromia Coffee Farmers Co-operative Union, was a decisive moment in the production of the film.<ref name="Production notes">{{cite web|title=Production Notes|url=http://blackgoldmovie.com/production-notes|publisher=Speakit Films|accessdate=14 February 2013}}</ref> The inspiring passion and determination of Tadesse, along with his continuous efforts to improve the lives of the farmers he represents, made Nick Francis and Marc James Francis decide much further in the production process to centre the film narrative around Tadesse's journey, his character functioning as a guide into the coffee world. The Ethiopian footage was filmed on two occasions (in 2003 and 2005), for six weeks each time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portafilter.net/2006/11/podcast-56-black-gold-movie.html |title=Podcast 56 - Black Gold The Movie |publisher=portafilter.net |date=2006-11-22 |accessdate=2011-03-20}}</ref>
After the first shoot in Ethiopia, the crew flew to Cancun to document the meetings of the [[World Trade Organization]], where pivotal decisions that affect Africa's economy and development were being made in setting the trade rules and where the struggle for fairer international trade rules was played out. Unprecedented, that year developing countries refused to be forced into signing agreements that were against their interests, and the WTO talks completely collapsed. After the team's return to the UK, they spent the following months developing a rough cut of ''Black Gold''. During these months, the direction of the film took shape, along with the rest of the necessary shoots meant to develop the thrust of the narrative. In 2005, the team returned to Ethiopia for further shoots.
Although [[Starbucks]], [[Sara Lee (corporation)|Sara Lee]], [[Procter & Gamble]], [[Kraft Foods|Kraft]], and [[Nestlé]]—the world's largest sellers of coffee—are mentioned in the film, all five companies declined invitations to be interviewed for the film.<ref name="Production notes" /> By the end of 2005, the final cut of ''Black Gold'' was done and officially premiered during the 2006‘s edition of Sundance Film Festival.
==Music== [[Andreas Kapsalis]], whom Marc James Francis and Nick Francis met during the Sundance Documentary Composers Lab, wrote the final soundtrack. In doing so, he used in part Mathew Coldrick's Ethiopian instrumental samples, recorded from Ethiopia. Joe Henson, Kunja Chatterton, and Mathew Herbert also contributed to the soundtrack.<ref>{{cite web|title=Soundtrack|url=http://blackgoldmovie.com/soundtrack|publisher=Speakit Films|accessdate=14 February 2013}}</ref>
==Awards and nominations== * WINNER: Best Achievement in Production - [[British Independent Film Awards 2007]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/event/ev0000127/2007|title=British Independent Film Awards|last=|first=|date=|website=[[IMDb]]|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> * WINNER: Contemporary Issues - San Francisco Black Film Festival (2006)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2006/06/prweb400803.htm|title=The San Francisco Black Film Festival Announces Winners; It's a Wrap for the 8th Annual San Francisco Black Film Festival|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Vigil|first=Delfin|title=Showcase of Black Film|url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Showcase-of-Black-Film-2495593.php|accessdate=13 March 2013|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=4 June 2006}}</ref> * NOMINEE: Best Documentary - British Independent Film Awards 2007<ref name=":0" /> * NOMINEE: Best Debut Director - British Independent Film Awards 2007<ref name=":0" /> * NOMINEE: Sundance Grand Jury Prize (2006)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://history.sundance.org/films/3629/black_gold|title=Black Gold|last=|first=|date=|website=Sundance Institute|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> * NOMINEE: Pare Lorentz Award (2006)<ref>{{cite 2013}}</ref> * NOMINEE: [[Index on Censorship|Index On Censorship]] Film Awards (2008)<ref>{{cite news|last=Sissay|first=Lemn|title=Why Ahlaam (Dreams) deserved to win|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2008/apr/22/howwepickedthebestfilm|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=14 February 2013|location=London|date=22 April 2008}}</ref> * Official Selection: [[Melbourne International Film Festival]] (2006)<ref>{{cite web|title=Black Gold|url=http://miff.com.au/60_years_of_miff/film_archive?movieid=12331|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130405112844/http://miff.com.au/60_years_of_miff/film_archive?movieid=12331|dead-url=yes|archive-date=5 web|title=Black Gold|url=http://www.fandor.com/films/black_gold|publisher=fandor.com|accessdate=19 February 2013}}</ref> * Official Selection: [[BFI London Film Festival|London Film Festival]] (2006)<ref>{{cite web|title=Black Gold|url=http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/title/817116|work=ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/|accessdate=19 February 2013|year=2006}}</ref> * Official Selection: FESPACO Pan-African Film Festival * Official Selection: [[Rome Film Festival]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Black Gold|url=http://www.romacinemafest.it/ecm/web/fcr/en/94/content/black-gold.0000.FILMEN86|publisher=Rome Film Festival|accessdate=19 February 2013|year=2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303234800/http://www.romacinemafest.it/ecm/web/fcr/en/94/content/black-gold.0000.FILMEN86|archivedate=3 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * Official Selection: [[Hot Docs Canadian International Documentary Festival]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Kumar|first=Mathew|title=Hot Docs Continues: The rest of the week’s picks.|url=http://torontoist.com/2006/05/hot_docs_contin/|publisher=Torontoist|accessdate=19 February 2013|date=May 2006}}</ref> * Official Selection: [[True/False Film Festival]] (2006) <ref>{{cite web|title=Black Gold|url=http://archives.truefalse.org/2006/films/blackgold.htm|publisher=True/False Film Festival|accessdate=13 March 2013}}</ref> * Official Selection: [[Human Rights Watch]] Film Festival (2006)<ref>{{cite news|last=Klawans|first=Stuart|title=Local Hero|url=http://www.thenation.com/article/local-hero|accessdate=13 March 2013|newspaper=The Nation}}</ref> * Official Selection: [[New Zealand International Film Festivals|New Zealand International Film Festival]] (2006)<ref>{{cite web|title=Festivals & Awards|url=http://blackgoldmovie.com/festivals-awards|publisher=Speakit Films|accessdate=13 March 2013}}</ref>
==Distribution== ''Black Gold'' has been released in the cinema and on DVD in over 40 countries: in the UK (Dogwoof), US (California Newsreel), Canada (Mongral Media), Australia (Madman), Germany, Spain, Netherlands, Scandinavia, and Japan. The film has also been broadcast on TV stations around the world including US (ITVS: Independent Lens), UK (Channel 4), Japan (NHK), Israel (DBS/YES), New Zealand (Documentary Channel), South Africa (SABC), South Korea (EBS), and the Middle East (Al-jazeera). It continues to be screened around the world.
''Black Gold'' went on to be seen in over 60 international film festivals including London, Rome, Berlin, Melbourne, Hong Kong, and Rio de Janeiro and has secured major broadcast deals around the world including [http://www.channel4.com/programmes/black-gold Channel 4] (UK), [https://www.pbs.org/independentlens/blackgold/economics.html PBS/Independent Lens] (US), Documentary Channel (Canada), NHK (Japan), and Al-jazeera (Middle East).<ref>{{cite web|title=IMPACT OF THE FILM BLACK GOLD: SOWING SEEDS FOR CHANGE|url=http://blackgoldmovie.com/impact|accessdate=14 February 2013}}</ref>
''Black Gold'' has attracted wide coverage in the media including features on CNN,<ref>{{cite news|last=CNN|title=CNN Report - Black Gold film shakes up coffee industry|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t-Xilsyd7Xo|accessdate=14 February 2013|year=2006}}</ref> BBC World, BBC News 24,<ref>{{cite news|title=BBC News - Live interview with Black Gold Directors Marc and Nick Francis and Kraft|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k2Nawcjzu_o|accessdate=14 February 2013|newspaper=BBC News 24|year=2006}}</ref> Sky News,<ref>{{cite news|title=Sky News - Marc & Nick Francis talk about Black Gold, trade & coffee|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3de0byEhx50|accessdate=14 February 2013|newspaper=SKY News|year=2006}}</ref> Bloomberg, The Observer,<ref>{{cite news|last=French|first=Phillip|title=Black Gold|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2007/jun/10/documentary.worldcinema|accessdate=12 March 2013|newspaper=The Observer|location=London|date=10 June 2007}}</ref> The Times,<ref name="The Times">{{cite news|last=Hoyle|first=Ben|title=A wake-up call to world’s coffee giants|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/arts/film/article2435182.ece|accessdate=13 March 2013|newspaper=The Times}}</ref> The Daily Telegraph,<ref>{{cite news|last=Gritten|first=David|title=Britain shines at Sundance|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/3649662/Britain-shines-at-Sundance.html|accessdate=13 March 2013|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|location=London|date=27 January 2006}}</ref> New York Times,<ref>{{cite news|last=Scott|first=A. O.|title=Sundance, Now a Study in Paradox|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/27/movies/27sund.html?_r=0|accessdate=14 February 2006|newspaper=The New York Times|date=27 January 2006}}</ref> LA Times,<ref name="LA Times" >{{cite news|last=Chocano|first=Carina|title=Poverty in that morning cup|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/jan/12/entertainment/et-black12|accessdate=14 February 2013|newspaper=LA Times|date=12 January 2007}}</ref> The Washington Post,<ref>{{cite news|last=Hornaday|first=Ann|title=Brewing 'Black Gold'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/12/07/AR2006120700574.html|accessdate=14 February 2013|newspaper=Washington Post|date=8 December 2006}}</ref> and South China Morning Post.<ref name="Forrest">{{cite news|last=Forrest|first=Adam|title=Grounds for complaint? Why a film about coffee|newspaper=The Sunday Herald|date=27 May 2007|pages=16–17}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Macnab|first=Geoffery|title=Black Gold|newspaper=Sight and Sound|date=24 May 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Dawson|first=Jeff|title=Wake up and smell the coffee|newspaper=The Sunday Times|date=4 June 2007|pages=10–11}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=David|title=British film-makers ask: what is the hidden cost of your £2 latte?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2007/may/27/foodanddrink.food|accessdate=12 March 2013|newspaper=The Observer|location=London|date=5 June 2007}}</ref>
==Reception and impact== In the first few weeks after the premiere, the film helped to generate donations approximately up to $25,000. The dilapidated school featured in the film was built.
Tadesse Meskela, the main character in ''Black Gold'', was able to increase the market price for his cooperative union's coffee. Tadesse Meskela was invited to 10 Downing Street, where he took his message directly to [[Tony Blair]].
After seeing the film, the UN have invited Tadesse to New York to do a presentation about his co-operatives at the 46th Session of the [[Commission for Social Development]].
''Black Gold'' was screened at the [[World Bank]] and [[European Union]], as part of debates about trade policy and development. The Ethiopian ambassadors based at Berlin, Washington, D.C., and London attended screenings.
''Black Gold'' was the first film to receive funding from BritDoc.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kopp|first=Ingrid|title=Your Film Can Change the World|url=http://workingfilms.org/blog/wp-content/uploads/2008/09/your-film-can-change-the-world.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101203173950/http://workingfilms.org/blog/wp-content/uploads/2008/09/your-film-can-change-the-world.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=3 December 2010|accessdate=12 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Evans|first=Chris|title=Black Gold: storm in a coffee cup|url=http://www.screendaily.com/black-gold-storm-in-a-coffee-cup/4033053.article#|accessdate=12 March 2013}}</ref>
==Corporate response to ''Black Gold''== Since the first showing of ''Black Gold'' during Sundance, Starbucks sent people to screenings of the film in what has been called by one journalist "going on a charm offensive".<ref>{{cite web|last=Carnevale|first=Rob|title=Black Gold - Marc and Nick Francis interview|url=http://www.indielondon.co.uk/Film-Review/black-gold-marc-and-nick-francis-interview|publisher=indielondon.co.uk|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Seager|first=Ashley|title=Starbucks stirred by fair trade film|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/jan/29/development.filmnews|accessdate=13 March 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|location=London|date=29 January 2007}}</ref> As the film became more and more popular, Starbucks flew Tadesse and four other African coffee producers to their Seattle headquarters for a weekend conference, which was seen by many as a PR stunt.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ethiopian coffee farmer Tadesse Meskela Gudeta tastes Indonesian coffee Thursday at Starbucks' African Coffee Celebration|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/default/photo/Ethiopian-coffee-farmer-Tadesse-Meskela-Gudeta-904004.php|publisher=Seattle Post-Intelligencer|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Siel|title=Black Gold: A Coffee Film That Has Starbucks Scared|url=http://www.treehugger.com/green-food/black-gold-a-coffee-film-that-has-starbucks-scared.html|publisher=treehugger.com|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref> Further, just before the film premiered at the London Film Festival in October 2006, a memo received by Starbucks staff from the headquarters leaked to the ''Black Gold forum''. The internal memo was sent out to inform all Starbucks employees that ''Black Gold'' was "incomplete and inaccurate".<ref name="Forrest" />
